Well, I'm getting out of my depth here but no, I don't think that is correct. A normal individual will produce the required amount of acid and enzymes at the right time, but no more. Perhaps very fatty food disrupts this process - it's possible but I cannot say because I don't know for sure.
When you are getting acid reflux, that indicates a problem with the valve/shincter that lets food into the stomach but not back out. When it is not functioning correctly, the stomach contents can be forced back out, the wrong way.
Again, I'm certainly no medical expert so you may want to do your own research.

From what I was told, most people start on 40 mg and then go back to 20. I did this. I find that only about one day a month I get serious breakthrough. So I don't worry and just keep taking 20 mg.
I have also found that if I take too much, my food doesn't digest properly and I throw up pretty much what looks like the food I ate, with the consistency of peanut butter. Last time it happened I gorged myself on cashews and I reckon I could have put them back together after they came up.
I have GORD, you might too. I would go back to the doctor. You may need more. But I'm not a doctor, so you should really speak to an expert.
Cheers mate.

HCl is a strong acid - it completely separates into H+ and Cl- ions in water - that is the definition of strong with regard to acids. But you must remember that the concentration of the acid in any situation is just as important. Yes we have 'strong' acid in our stomach but it it isn't that concentrated - hence the enzymes that help out.
If you made a solution of HCl at the same concentration as is in our stomach, you would find that you could stick your hand in it for quite a while before it really hurt. You notice it burns and stings a bit when you vomit - it's coming into contact with some pretty sensitive mucous membranes but it isn't that bad, just unpleasant.
I can personally say I know, because I have done it many times, with both hydrochloric and sulfuric acids. It gets on your skin and after a while it starts to itch and burn so you just wash it off. You will know when it's really concentrated, trust me.
I used to work with it all the time and was never very careful with safety. It's your eyes you must worry about. Wear those fucking goggles if you value your eyesight.
Thanks. I'll keep that in mind
Thanks mate. Yes, I do have the DLCs but I'm only at level 18 right now.

Your stomach acid isn't very strong (or more properly, concentrated), in the scheme of things. Much of the work is done by enzymes, in conjunction with the acid. Furthermore, the acid is produced as needed. You don't walk around with half a litre of concentrated acid sloshing around.
The acid is produced by special cells. Some people, like me, have over active ones. We take drugs known as proton pump inhibitors, so we don't make too much acid (protons).

WRITING.TITLE: Having some trouble with some equilibrium questions

What happens when 3 moles of each are put into the flask?

To be honest, toluene probably won't help you in a naturally aspirated road car. Modern fuels have enough knock resistance to drive any average car pretty hard. Toluene would let you advance timing significantly but it's still probably a waste of time.
High performance turbocharged engines would be a different story - but you aren't going for economy there - you are going for performance and reliability. That's where you you would use toluene - so you can wind up the boost pressure to stupid levels without the thing shitting itself in an instant.
The fuel blend you buy at the pump is pretty damn good. If it weren't, some company would capitalise on that real quick. And if you use fuel that is significantly different, your car's management system would not be able to cope and something might be damaged. Most engine management systems are designed to advance the timing until the onset of knock, retard it and repeat that process. Using some exotic fuel would be outside the window of their capabilities.
You could approach the various oil companies if you wanted to try it out but I doubt it would be worth it. At high levels of toluene, the fuel doesn't vaporise properly and you need to heat it - I'm not sure at what point that would be - you'd have to consult the tables to see what vaporises at what temperature and compare it.
Sorry to disappoint but basically fuel companies have this sewn up. No one is going to sell or use TEL, which would in theory be the answer to your question.
Feel free to ask any other questions you have. I'll do my best.
Is that a bad thing?
EVERY time I want to do anything with fucking Steam, I have to get a code from my email to verify it's me, on the same computer, on the same fucking day. Every time, without fail.
Buzzfeed? Are you for real?

Yep. Cumulative revs. That's it. Make a mistake and your done for the day. I saw Gerhard Berger saying you had to get on the throttle up to two seconds early and try and anticipate when the power would come on - power could literally double in the space of 1000 revs on the tacho. One mistake and you just slide off.

The rest was n-heptane to meet the FIA requirements. Toluene isn't really any better or worse than the blends of petrol we use anywhere else (it is also a component in most blends of petrol) in terms of safety. It's just super effective at preventing detonations.
Try not to get it on yourself and don't wash your hands in it, etc. The usual safety precautions. Many octane boosting products contain large amounts of it. Yes, it is carcinogenic like a vast array of hydrocarbons but it's not a huge problem if you handle it safely. It's very similar to benzene - it's just a benzene ring with a methyl group attached.

WRITING.TITLE: Two questions I am having trouble with (equilibrium reactions)
WRITING.TEXT:
The first one is very simple but I got it wrong. It simply states a reaction has Kc = 1.5 where A(g) = 2B(g)
What happens when 3 mol of each are put into the flask?
I said A decreases and B increases, as the ratio is 1:2. But the answer is the opposite of what I thought. Why?
The other question says Kc = 1.6 x 10^-10 for the reaction:
2SO3(g) = 2SO2(g) + O2(g)
Then it asks what Kc is for:
SO2(g) + 1/2O2(g) = SO3(g)
It's the same reaction, just backwards. I thought the rate would be the same but opposite. Apparently, that is not the case. The answer is 7.9 x 10^4. Can someone tell me why?
Also - how do you do subscripts here?

I wish people would learn the difference between turbo lag and boost threshold.
That thing never had 1500 hp, either. None of them did. No one had a dyno that went that high. They just estimated it - and it was closer to 1300 hp in qualifying guise.
They were running up to 5.5 bar (80 psi) boost, so they had to use fuel that was ~84% toluene (methylbenzene) to combat knock. From what I had read, the engine life at that much boost was ~25,000 *cumulative* revs. That's it - two to three minutes for qualifying runs and then it died.
An RUF.

No, doing that will not leave any useful amount of N2 in the petrol - and I don't see how somehow dissolving nitrogen into petrol would do anything, anyway. All you will do is speed up the evaporation rate.
Ethanol does not contain nitrogen. I'm not sure how that idea is supposed to work in therms of 'nitrogen enrichment' - whatever that is. Ethanol is an oxygenate - a fuel that already contains oxygen. You need to use more of it to get the same power. It also has lower energy density. It is a poor choice for a normal road going car. But it has excellent knock characteristics for racing.
What would really help would be TEL - tetraethyl lead. A fantastic knock combating compound. But obviously you can't use it anymore. It is an excellent anti-knock compound. One of the best.
The chemical I would use is toluene (methylbenzene). Toluene is possibly the best hydrocarbon fuel you could get for a petrol engine. In the 80s the Formula 1 cars used to it to allow them to run stupendous boost levels in the turbocharged cars. Some cars could run up to 5.5 bar (80 psi) of boost for short periods.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toluene

They need to prove the allegations and then get cooperation, if the other country you reside in has an extradition treaty.
Take, for instance, piracy of software/copyright - there is no fucking way in hell an Australian agency is going to cooperate with the US.
There was a famous case called the Dallas Buyer's Club (some lame US movie) - DBC marched into the Australian court system and demanded they be able to sue people under US style law. They were literally laughed out of court. The US plaintiffs thought they could sue people in Australia, just like they do in America.
But it doesn't work like that. In Australia, we don't have punitive damages - you can't say someone is liable for untold amounts of money because they shared the movie dozens of times. All you can do is sue them for one copy of the movie. So, the DBC lawyers quickly found out that they could only sue people for about 30 bucks each. And the presiding judge made them apply for each and every case through him. Needless to say, the DBC lawyers quickly found out that we don't dance to American tunes.
US law stops at US borders.
Yep. It's fucking funny when dickheads get caught. I used to take great delight in reporting them when I worked in retail. Be a pro or don't fucking bother, you useless cunt.
